text: December 30, 1997
label: BODY

text: MEMORANDUM
label: HH3

text: TO:
label: BODY

text: USAID/Egypt Director, John R. Westley
label: BODY

text: FROM:
label: BODY

text: RIG/A/Cairo, Lou Mundy
label: BODY

text: SUBJECT:
label: BODY

text: Audit of USAID/Egypt's Review and Certification of Unliquidated Obligations for
label: BODY

text: Project and Non-Project Assistance
label: BODY

text: This is our report on the subject audit.  In finalizing the report, we considered the Mission's comments
label: BODY

text: on the draft report, which are included in Appendix II.  The report contains one recommendation
label: BODY

text: which is closed upon issuance.
label: BODY

text: We appreciate the cooperation and assistance provided to the auditors on this assignment.
label: BODY

text: Background
label: HH2

text: This audit is part of the Office of Inspector General's (OIG) worldwide review of USAID obligations
label: BODY

text: for project and non-project assistance.  The OIG's Division of Performance Audits (IG/A/PA) is
label: BODY

text: leading this worldwide effort, with the assistance of auditors from all OIG offices of Regional
label: BODY

text: Inspectors General.
label: BODY

text: The worldwide audit is limited to obligations for project and non-project assistance which had
label: BODY

text: unliquidated balances on September 30, 1996.  It does not cover obligations funded with U.S.-owned
label: BODY

text: local currency, obligations for disaster relief, or obligations maintained by USAID for the Trade and
label: BODY

text: Development Agency.
label: BODY

text: IG/A/PA randomly selected USAID sites for detailed audit work and also determined the number of
label: BODY

text: unliquidated obligations to be randomly selected and then reviewed at each site.  A total of 19 sites
label: BODY

text: (USAID/Washington and 18 missions) were selected for review.  USAID/Egypt was among those
label: BODY

text: missions randomly selected for review.
label: BODY

text: Mission records indicate that, as of September 30, 1996, USAID/Egypt had 195 unliquidated
label: BODY

text: obligations for project and non-project assistance with balances totalling $2.2 billion. Sixty-five
label: BODY

text: unliquidated obligations for project and non-project assistance with balances totalling $1.6 billion were
label: BODY

text: selected for detailed audit work.
label: BODY

text: The level of funding for the USAID/Egypt program is based on a congressional earmark of $815
label: BODY

text: million annually.  Since 1991, the Foreign Operations Export Financing and Related Programs
label: BODY

text: Appropriations Acts, have allowed funds obligated before their expiration date to remain available until
label: BODY

text: expended.
label: BODY

text: Audit Objective
label: HH2

text: The worldwide audit was designed to answer the following question:
label: BODY

text: Did USAID/Egypt review and certify its unliquidated obligations for project and non-project
label: HH3

text: assistance in accordance with U.S. laws and regulations and USAID policies and procedures?
label: HH3

text: Appendix I contains a discussion of the scope and methodology for audit work conducted at
label: BODY

text: USAID/Egypt.
label: BODY

text: Audit Findings
label: HH2

text: Did USAID/Egypt review and certify its unliquidated obligations for project and non-project
label: HH3

text: assistance in accordance with U.S. laws and regulations and USAID policies and procedures?
label: HH3

text: For the items tested, USAID/Egypt reviewed and certified its unliquidated obligations for project and
label: BODY

text: non-project assistance in accordance with U.S. laws and regulations and USAID policies and
label: BODY

text: procedures.  We found no invalid obligations
label: BODY

text: 1 among the items tested.  We noted that the Mission
label: BODY

text: conducted monthly pipeline analyses and periodic Section 1311 reviews to ensure that unliquidated
label: BODY

text: obligations and commitments were valid and still needed.  However, 6 of the 219 tested commitments
label: BODY

text: had excessive balances totalling $2,064,406 as of September 30, 1996.  While the worldwide audit was
label: BODY

text: limited to unliquidated obligations/commitments as of September 30, 1996, we expanded the scope of
label: BODY

text: our audit at USAID/Egypt to cover such obligations/commitments through August 15, 1997.  In this
label: BODY

text: expanded period, we found that 11 of the 219 unliquidated commitments reviewed, totaling $318,569,
label: BODY

text: should have been decommitted.
label: BODY

text: Some Commitments Had Excessive
label: HH3

text: 1GAO's Principles of Federal Appropriations Law defines an obligation as "some action that creates a liability
label: BODY

text: or definite commitment on the part of the government to make a disbursement at some later time."  USAID
label: BODY

text: Financial Management Bulletin, Part II, No. 14A, defines a commitment as "funds set aside [for an obligation] to
label: BODY

text: pay for goods or services being procured."
label: BODY

text: Balances As of September 30, 1996
label: HH3

text: Each year USAID's Bureau for Policy and Program Coordination issues guidance for the preparation
label: BODY

text: of mission and office budgets.  For the period under audit, the guidance required that obligations
label: BODY

text: should provide funding for at least the first 18 months, but not for more than 24 months and that
label: BODY

text: continuing activities' obligations should be sufficient to fund anticipated expenses for no more than 12
label: BODY

text: months beyond the end of the fiscal year in which the obligation takes place. These are called "forward
label: BODY

text: funding" guidelines.  However, in February 1993, USAID/Egypt was granted a blanket exemption
label: BODY

text: from these guidelines.
label: BODY

text: We reviewed 219 commitments totalling $897 million under 65 obligations.  Of the 219 commitments
label: BODY

text: we tested, we found only 6 of the commitments, totalling $2.1 million, had excessive (no longer
label: BODY

text: needed) balances as prescribed by applicable U.S. laws, regulations and USAID policies and
label: BODY

text: procedures.
label: BODY

text: We noted that the Mission continuously reviewed unliquidated obligations/commitments to assure their
label: BODY

text: continued validity.  Pipeline analyses were conducted monthly.  We reviewed the fiscal year 1996 year
label: BODY

text: end "Section 1311 review"
label: BODY

text: 2 and found overall it was adequately conducted and documented.
label: BODY

text: Despite the pipeline analyses and Section 1311 reviews, six commitments totalling $2,064,406 should
label: BODY

text: have been decommitted as of September 30, 1996 (see Appendix III).  One commitment was for $2.0
label: BODY

text: million and represented 99 percent of the total recommended for decommitment.  The reasons these
label: BODY

text: commitments were not decommitted varied.  For example, the Mission did not decommit the balances
label: BODY

text: at September 30, 1996 because financial management personnel anticipated a commitment document
label: BODY

text: extension that never occurred or they anticipated additional payments needed to be processed.  In
label: BODY

text: general more vigorous application of existing analyses and monitoring procedures, and more persistent
label: BODY

text: follow-up on unliquidated balances would result in more prompt decommitment actions.  Nevertheless,
label: BODY

text: because the Mission decommitted these commitments prior to our audit, we are not making any
label: BODY

text: recommendation.
label: BODY

text: Other Matters -
label: HH3

text: Commitments After September 30, 1996
label: HH3

text: While the worldwide audit was limited to unliquidated obligations/commitments as of September 30,
label: BODY

text: 1996, we expanded the scope of our audit at USAID/Egypt to cover such obligations/commitments
label: BODY

text: through August 15, 1997.  In this expanded period, we found that 11 of the 219 unliquidated
label: BODY

text: commitments reviewed should have been decommitted.
label: BODY

text: 2Section 1311 of the Supplemental Appropriations Act of 1955
label: BODY

text: Recommendation No. 1:  We recommend that USAID/Egypt decommit $318,569 in
label: BODY

text: excess balances identified as of August 15, 1997 and as described in Appendix IV of this
label: BODY

text: report.
label: BODY

text: We reviewed the 219 commitments identified in our sample for the year ending September 30, 1996
label: BODY

text: and applied the same criteria as stated above, that was: to determine if they were valid and still needed
label: BODY

text: for the purpose and the amount committed as of August 15, 1997.
label: BODY

text: We noted that the Mission continuously reviewed unliquidated obligations/commitments to assure
label: BODY

text: continued validity for the purpose and the amount of the obligation/commitment.  Pipeline analyses
label: BODY

text: were conducted and presented Mission-wide quarterly.  We reviewed the 1997 mid-fiscal year Section
label: BODY

text: 1311 review and found overall it was adequately conducted and documented.
label: BODY

text: Despite the quarterly pipeline analyses and Section 1311 review, we found for the 219 commitments
label: BODY

text: tested, 11 had excessive balances that should have been decommitted as of August 15, 1997.  See
label: BODY

text: Appendix IV for a listing.  The total amount we considered excessive was $318,569.
label: BODY

text: Again, the reasons these amounts were not decommitted varied from case to case; however, for the
label: BODY

text: majority of cases, financial management personnel were not aware final vouchers had been paid.  In
label: BODY

text: general, greater persistence in following up on unliquidated commitment balances would help assure
label: BODY

text: more timely decommitment action.  The Mission should take action to decommit balances that are no
label: BODY

text: longer needed.
label: BODY

text: Management Comments and Our Evaluation
label: HH2

text: The Mission agreed with the audit recommendation.
label: BODY

text: In response to Recommendation No. 1, the Mission decommitted $318,569.  Based on the action
label: BODY

text: taken by the Mission, a management decision has been reached and final action has been taken.  As a
label: BODY

text: result, we consider Recommendation No. 1 closed.
label: BODY

text: Appendix I
label: HH3

text: Page 1 of 2
label: BODY

text: Scope
label: HH2

text: This audit is part of the Office of Inspector General's (OIG) worldwide review of USAID's obligations
label: BODY

text: for project and non-project assistance.  The worldwide audit is limited to obligations for project and
label: BODY

text: non-project assistance which had unliquidated balances on September 30, 1996.  It does not cover
label: BODY

text: obligations funded with U.S.-owned local currency, obligations for disaster relief, or obligations
label: BODY

text: maintained by USAID for the Trade and Development Agency.
label: BODY

text: In conformance with the worldwide audit, the Regional Inspector General/Cairo audited
label: BODY

text: USAID/Egypt's review and certification of unliquidated obligations (and the 219 commitments under
label: BODY

text: those obligations) for project and non-project assistance, as of September 30, 1996.  In addition, we
label: BODY

text: audited USAID/Egypt's review and certification process as of August 15, 1997.  The audit was
label: BODY

text: conducted at USAID/Egypt, from June 18, 1997 through November 16, 1997, and was performed in
label: BODY

text: accordance with generally accepted government auditing standards.
label: BODY

text: Methodology
label: HH2

text: At the request of IG/A/PA, USAID/Egypt compiled a list of its obligations for project and non-project
label: BODY

text: assistance which had unliquidated balances on September 30, 1996.  USAID/Egypt's list contained 195
label: BODY

text: unliquidated obligations with balances totalling $2.2 billion.  We randomly selected 65 obligations
label: BODY

text: totalling $1.6 billion, under which there were 219 commitments totalling $897 million, from the list for
label: BODY

text: detailed audit testing.  Random sampling will allow the OIG to make Agencywide projections based on
label: BODY

text: field work performed at a limited number of sites.  We have not, however, projected the results of our
label: BODY

text: audit work at USAID/Egypt to the Mission as a whole.
label: BODY

text: Because the accuracy and completeness of the Mission's list was crucial to our ability to make
label: BODY

text: Agencywide projections, we interviewed appropriate Mission staff about their methodology in
label: BODY

text: preparing the list and reconciled the list and its totals to other Mission reports.
label: BODY

text: 3Note that we did not establish a materiality threshold for reporting on our work at USAID/Egypt because
label: BODY

text: guidance for the worldwide audit required us to report all instances of non-compliance with USAID guidance.
label: BODY

text: SCOPE AND
label: HH1

text: METHODOLOGY
label: H1

text: Appendix I
label: HH3

text: Page 2 of 2
label: BODY

text: While conducting our fieldwork at USAID/Egypt, we also performed limited tests of compliance with
label: BODY

text: Agency and Mission procedures related to Section 1311 reviews and eipeline reviews of obligations for
label: BODY

text: project and non-project assistance.
label: BODY

text: We reviewed each obligation to determine whether it was valid in accordance with the provisions of 31
label: BODY

text: U.S.C. 1501(a) and decisions of the U.S. General Accounting Office.  When amounts were questioned,
label: BODY

text: and if necessary, we contacted responsible activity managers and contracting/grant officers in order to
label: BODY

text: make a determination regarding the validity of the obligation/commitment.
label: BODY
